Class Task1

  • java.lang.Object
    • Task1

  • public class Task1
extends java.lang.Object
    Task for HH school
    Finding minimal distance (min(d=sqrt((x1-x2)^2+(y1-y2)^2))) between multiple points
    Since:
    09.10.2015
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Volobuev-AN

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static double dMinDistance
      Variable to store current minimal distance, we initialize it with very big value at first step

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Task1() 

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static void checkDistance(Task1.Point p1, Task1.Point p2)
      Method to check if current distance between two points is less than minimal distance
      and update current minimal value if it's true
      static void findMin(Task1.Point[] vSrc, Task1.Point[] vAux, int nLow, int nHigh)
      Recurent method to find minimal distance implementing Preparata's algorithm, based on map-reduce technique (like quick sort)
      static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
      Entry point to application
      Initial values are set by user (by input them in dialog mode):
      Input points:
      10 10 PRESS ENTER
      20 10 PRESS ENTER
      20 15 PRESS ENTER
      PRESS ENTER
      5.0

      Two ways to count minimal distance:
      1) Straight one O(N*N)
      2) Preparata's algorithm (apprx.
      static void merge(Task1.Point[] vSrc, Task1.Point[] vAux, int nLow, int nMiddle, int nHigh)
      Method to merge arrays by special rule: compare left and right's parts and move them

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Entry point to application
        Initial values are set by user (by input them in dialog mode):
        Input points:
        10 10 PRESS ENTER
        20 10 PRESS ENTER
        20 15 PRESS ENTER
        PRESS ENTER
        5.0

        Two ways to count minimal distance:
        1) Straight one O(N*N)
        2) Preparata's algorithm (apprx. O(N*logN))
